title: MacKenzie Scott Donates $3.86 Billion to 465 Organizations in Less Than a Year; Billionaire philanthropist gave to groups including Planned Parenthood, Habitat for Humanity and the Boys & Girls Clubs of America, aiming to support needs of underrepresented groups
text:
"When our giving team focuses on any system in which people are struggling, we don't assume that we, or any other single group, can know how to fix it," Ms. Scott wrote in a Medium post. "We don't advocate for particular policies or reforms. Instead, we seek a portfolio of organizations that supports the ability of all people to participate in solutions."

Ms. Scott, formerly married to Amazon.com Inc. founder Jeff Bezos, has a net worth of about $54.4 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, a ranking of the wealthiest people around the globe. Ms. Scott received 4% of Amazon's shares as part of her 2019 divorce settlement with Mr. Bezos.

She signed a pledge to give away most of her wealth the year she divorced Mr. Bezos.

The Giving Pledge was created in 2010 by Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates, his now ex-wife Melinda French Gates and Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Chief Executive Warren Buffett, and encourages the world's richest people to give more than half of their wealth to charitable causes.

Ms. Scott has given away more than $12 billion to more than 1,000 groups since her 2019 pledge, according to her posts on Medium. "I have a disproportionate amount of money to share," she wrote in 2019 when she joined the Giving Pledge.

Habitat for Humanity International along with 84 U.S. Habitat affiliate organizations received $436 million from Ms. Scott, the organization said earlier this week. Habitat for Humanity will use its portion of the funding to boost the supply of affordable housing and on other housing measures.

The Boys & Girls Clubs of America and various affiliates were awarded with a $281 million gift from Ms. Scott, the largest gift given in the organization's 160-year history, it said. The groups said the donation will help it expand its youth-development programs across the U.S.

The recipients also included Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Ms. Scott donated $275 million to the national organization and 21 affiliates. It was the largest gift from a single donor in Planned Parenthood's history, the organization said.

"This funding will support our efforts to advance health equity by eliminating racial and structural barriers for our patients in the communities where Planned Parenthood works," said Alexis McGill Johnson, CEO of Planned Parenthood Federation of America.
